Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal Investigator (PI) plans to apply the theory of geometric braids to study a variety of problems in contact geometry. Especially, she introduces a new notion, open book foliation, that has its origin in braid theory. She intends to apply the open book foliation to investigate contact structures for three dimensional manifolds and find new tightness and overtwistedness criteria. In addition, the PI continues to study the relationship between the braid index, a classical knot invariant, and various geometric quantities such as writhes, HOMFLY polynomials, the self-linking number in contact geometry, and Khovanov-Rozansky homology. The PI will disseminate the results of her research by advising her current and potential graduate students at the University of Iowa, and by interacting with both undergraduate and graduate students through her seminars and lectures. The projects afford undergraduate and graduate students the opportunity to study contact geometry from both a theoretical and practical point of view. Developing computer graphic techniques with a view towards visualizing the open book foliations will provide students with an excellent introduction to a modern mathematics

The PI will work on several projects in low-dimensional topology. Low dimensional topology is broadly applicable in a variety of scientific disciplines including biology and medicine where, for example, protein folding mechanisms and DNA structure play a seminal role. Results of the proposed projects will likely stimulate communication and collaboration between the PI and researchers within mathematics as well as other scientific disciplines.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the period of 06/01/2016 to 05/31/2017, the PI finished two papers, both joint with Tetsuya Ito (Osaka University) and under review for publication.

The first paper is titled ``Positive factorizations of symmetric mapping classes''.

The PI studied a question raised by Etnyre and Van Horn-Morris; whether a symmetric mapping class admitting a positive factorization is a lift of a quasi-positive braid. She answered the question affirmatively for mapping classes satisfying certain cyclic conditions. The problem lies over three different fields; namely, mapping class group theory, symplectic & contact geometry, and braid theory.

The second paper is titled ``The defect of Bennequin-Eliashberg inequality and Bennequin surfaces''. The Bennequin-Eliashberg inequality is known to be a fundamental tool in the classification of contact structures.

It is easy to observe that the inequality is sharp on every strongly quasipositive knots and links in the 3-dimensional sphere.
The converse of the fact has been questioned more than decade by a number of well-established mathematicians, including Rudolph, Etnyre, Hedden and van Horn-Morris. If the inequality is sharp on a knot then is the knot strongly quasipositive?

The PI answered the question affirmatively under condition that the fractional Dehn twist coefficient of the knot is high, more precisely, greater than 1.

The PI further extended the question from the setting of the  3-dimensional sphere to generic 3-dimensional manifolds. She also answered the generalized question affirmatively under certain conditions.

Turning the attention from sharpness of the Bennequin-Eliashberg inequality, the gap (non-sharpness) of the inequality is also investigated in the paper. The PI gave a geometric meaning of the defect number of the inequality.

The PI has advised three Ph.D. students and one post-doc fellow in University of Iowa. Among them, Camila Ramirez, who is from the under-represented group in STEM fields, earned a Ph.D. in May 2017. 

The PI has a workshop style lecture to a local K6 students in Iowa City in December 2016.


Last Modified: 07/04/2017
Modified by: Keiko Kawamuro

The problem lies over three different fields; namely, mapping class group theory, symplectic & contact geometry, and braid theory. The second paper is titled ``The defect of Bennequin-Eliashberg inequality and Bennequin surfaces''. The Bennequin-Eliashberg inequality is known to be a fundamental tool in the classification of contact structures. It is easy to observe that the inequality is sharp on every strongly quasipositive knots and links in the 3-dimensional sphere. Turning the attention from sharpness of the Bennequin-Eliashberg inequality, the gap (non-sharpness) of the inequality is also investigated in the paper.
